body: @bvaradar can you please followup and see if this is generally applicable?
Rough plan : document this better + support an option to pass in acceptable partition paths
We need to test this thoroughly across all query engines & some of our users are still on 1.x.. So like to keep things as it is for now. Agree with the direction of moving towards Hive 2.x though

Good point.. This is similar to how we also do this. But I was wondering if , a user who wants to delete would just be interested in passing in the `HoodieKey`s alone. i.e just `_hoodie_record_key` and `_hoodie_partition_path`, without generating the other fields? 

Alternatively, what do you think about adding a `DELETE` operation to the spark datasource options and then requiring that the incoming dataframe be of a specific schema type (i.e with just 2 fields as I mentioned above), then internally we can always use a `DeletePayload` to issue the upsert underneath will delete all touched keys.. Do you think this would be more generalized?
Can `hoodie.insert.shuffle.parallelism` and `hoodie.upsert.shuffle.parallelism` also automatically set parallelism to deal with different data size, please?

+1 .. 

But there are two aspects to this. 

1. Making sure the insert/upsert/bulk_insert shuffle parallelism is large enough for us to consume to input. (I think Spark 2.4 gets rid of the 2GB limitation that annoys us all here)
2. Sizing it in such way that it generates minimal number of files..

But it exists in Hive's lib.

@BigdataGit Hudi continues to use Hive 1.x libs at the moment but we've tested that you should be able to talk to a Hive 2.x metastore from a Hive 1.x compiled Hudi. This ticket is talking about upgrading the client (HUDI) to Hive 2.x. 

On the other hand, the above exception tells me there is some jar conflict in the way you're bundling and running HiveSyncTool. How are you running/executing the tool ? Can you take a look at your hadoop classpath to see if there's something amiss ?

There isn't any generic recommended spark duration, it depends on a lot of factors such as amount of data ingested, parallelism of your job, how long it takes for you to write a 256 MB parquet file in your cluster etc which is best controlled by the clients. 
Having said that, here is what I'm saying : 

1. Using bulkInsert() -> Depending on the spread of your data, this may create some small files. The bulkInsert() API does NOT do small file sizing, so in a scenario where you keep performing bulkInserts() on a dataset, you will end up creating small files.
2. Using upsert() -> This API takes a bunch of inserts and updates, applies the updates to existing data in files and pads the inserts to existing small files. If the number of inserts << the number of small files, it will take a long time for all the small files to be padded enough to reach 128MB file size.

So in summary, if you are using bulkInsert() repeatedly, you can see the side effect. If you are using upsert() after a bunch of small files are already lying around in your dataset, depending on how many inserts you are performing every batch, it will take sometime for all small files to be padded. 
Hope this makes things more clear.

I have few more questions on it,

1. Does HUDI support composite partition columns  ?
2. Does HUDI support  for composite primary key ?
3. Does HUDI support gz file as source ?

Let me know more details if answer of any of the question is yes.

Also when we are running on 50 gb data it is taking more time in last job of collect  in commit method. So is there any other way of doing history load with Peta Byte scale.

@BigdataGit hey did you resolve this ? things working? Hive 2.x should be working.,

Ah the cores things is turning out to be real pain. sorry about that. We will prioritize this in feb. 

>> Does HUDI support composite partition columns ?

Hudi just treats partitionpath as a string, separated by `/`. You can customize it based on how you want it. Does that help? 

>> Does HUDI support for composite primary key ?

Yes. But, again, you can combine the composite keys into a string and make it the key. Hudi adds a special _hoodie_record_key field to your data with this combined value.

>> Does HUDI support gz file as source ?

Hudi DeltaStreamer does support avro and json/gz files as input. Does that work? It should be easy to add a new file type.

>> Also when we are running on 50 gb data it is taking more time in last job of collect in commit method. 

If you can paste your spark UI and configs, we can help tune.. Have you look at the configuration page? 

>> So is there any other way of doing history load with Peta Byte scale.

Not following. Are you asking if we have a tool to do bulk import? There is one for parquet datasets.

@vinothchandar Confirmed when we use lazy_reading, blocks are not merged until all are read so multiple rollbacks just rolls back data blocks. I'll see how to add a test case with partial compaction and then rollback to simulate the scenario in our production environment.

Please add me too!
yijia.go@gmail.com

@melin We haven't vetted the project with spark 2.4, this is something that we plan to do here : https://github.com/uber/hudi/issues/549. As part of that upgrade we can definitely upgrade the parquet version which requires making sure parquet upgrades don't break any backwards compatibility. In the meantime, if this is something you can change in your branch and make it work, that could be an option.

if I made the WriteStatus only carry the HoodieKey and HoodieRecordLocation, instead of HoodieRecord, would that be a problem?

We do some record counting as part of handling markSuccess(). These are used for tracking completeness metrics. We do need Payload along with HoodieKey for this purpose during markSuccess. After the call is over we can decide to just keep HoodieKey & HoodieRecordLocation. That should be fine.

Okay, then I can't just skip calling markSuccess() ? I ll find a way to push this inside the default WriteStatus implementation, such that we don't keep incurring overhead from holding all HoodieRecord that are written (payload is deflated after marking success anyway). That should be transparent to whatever you are doing? 

Does your WriteStatus impl still rely on some base class methods? or you override them all? @ovj ?
We are only overriding markSuccess() and markFailure() methods. All other methods we are using it from parent WriteStatus class as is.
okay gtk. will add you to the PR, if I pursue this

@pshivkumar How many executors are you using ? Essentially `--num-executors` is a spark parameter using which you can supply the number of executors. From the stacktrace, I can say the following is happening : Spark has something called a shuffle service that helps shuffle the data and write them to the local file system to be accessed by spark. If you are using a really low number of executors, this forces all the data to be shuffled to those small number of nodes leading to out of disk issue on those nodes. 
If you num executors is lower than 10 for this job, try bumping it up.

Jobs running over 3 days is uncommon for Hudi jobs unless you are doing some sort of bulkInsert for few 100 terabytes of data. I think there's something we are missing here.
1. What's the `compactionTool` that you speak of as the main class ? Is this just a Hudi spark job ?
2. What's your input batch size ?
3. I see that the location of the hudi table shows 1.6 G, were you already able to ingest some data into a hudi table ?
4. Can you share you Hudi configs along with the spark configs here please, as @vinothchandar mentioned, a spark UI snapshot would help immensely. 

At Uber, we are able to ingest 100's of gigabytes of data within 30-60 mins into hudi datasets. Our spark jobs vary in number of executors depending on the size of the input batch.
Closing this issue as the corresponding PR is merged.
